components.label: Content
HTML
components.content:
Welcome! This Workflow Checklist will lead you through the Toolkit for Evaluation and Design (TED). The toolkit is explained here.

The Workflow Checklist provides a step-by-step pathway that is customized to reflect the characteristics of your program, core service or policy initiative.

Along this pathway, you will find links to the templates and accompanying guidance that you will need to complete the design and conduct evaluation. The documentation can be accessed through the toolkits intranet site. You can go directly to the intranet site to locate any templates or guidance you might need: Quick Links to all Guidance and Templates.

You can return to this workflow checklist at any time. Remember to save your progress by pressing the Save as a Draft button at the top right before you leave.

components.label: Name of the program, core service, or policy initiative.
Is this a particularly small program or core service with a total budget of less than $100,000 and a duration of less than 1 year?

values.label: No. (This is the default response for most of programs, core services and policy initiatives.)

components.html: You have confirmed that the program or core service is small and short, with a total budget of less than $100,000 and a duration of less than 1 year. If that is not the case, please change your response to "No". If this is correct, then please close this Workflow Checklist. You should proceed without incorporating evaluation into your program or core service.
components.label: Content
Is it a program, core service, or policy initiative?
Is it a new program or a program already in progress?
Is it core service that is already in progress or is it a new core service?
components.description: If it's a new phase of a core service, then please select 'New Core Service'.

components.label: How many years of implementation are remaining?
HTML
components.content: The first step is to read the guidance on incorporating evaluation into programs and core services already in progress.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
See the guidance on initial program design steps for pointers on identification, scoping, design and appraisal.

As you create documents related to program design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
See the guidance on initial program design steps, which can also provide pointers for a new core service on identification, scoping, design and appraisal.

As you create documents related to design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
See the guidance on initial program design steps, which can also provide pointers for a new policy initiative on identification, scoping, design and appraisal.

As you create documents related to design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: HTML
components.content: As you create documents related to program design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: HTML
components.content: As you create documents related to core service design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your program has less than six months before it ends.

The guidance on incorporating evaluation into programs and core services already in progress advises you to consider:
  • Creating a Logic Model as soon as possible, to inform the Final Evaluation Report.
  • Creating a Table of Indicators if it can build on some indicators that are already being monitored.
  • Completing a Final Evaluation Report, upon completion.
As you create documents related to program design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: Is it an S-CAP funded program?
HTML
components.content:
Read the guidance for S-CAP funded programs. This explains how to:
  • Link S-CAP reporting to evaluation
  • Synchronize the timing of reviews
  • Incorporate application-based funding into a logic model
It will help to minimize duplication and thereby streamline your work.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your next steps:
  • Go to the Logic Model page to download the template and read the guidance to help you to create a logic model.
  • Go to the Table of Indicators page; review the template and guidance to see if completing the table is feasible.
  • Go to the Final Evaluation Report page to download the template and accompanying guidance, in preparation for the completion date.
  • Close this page. You do not need to continue with this Workflow Checklist.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your program has less than 18 months before it ends.

According to the guidance on incorporating evaluation into programs and core services already in progress you need to:
  • Create a Logic Model
  • Create a Table of Indicators
  • Complete a Final Evaluation Report, upon completion.
As you create documents related to program design and evaluation, it is important that you save final versions in a way that they can be retrieved in the future. Please follow the procedures set out in the records management guidance.

components.label: Is it an S-CAP funded program?
HTML
components.content:
Read the guidance for S-CAP funded programs. This explains how to:
  • Link S-CAP reporting to evaluation
  • Synchronize the timing of reviews
  • Incorporate application-based funding into a logic model
It will help to minimize duplication and thereby streamline your work.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your next steps:
  • Go to the Logic Model page to complete the template, using the accompanying guidance.
  • Go to the Table of Indicators page to complete the template, using the accompanying guidance
  • Go to the Final Evaluation Report page to download the template and read the guidance, in preparation for program completion.
  • Close this page. You do not need to continue with this Workflow Checklist.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
You will need to complete an Evaluation Assessment to determine the appropriate Level of Evaluation. It involves answering a series questions about the program, core service or policy initiative, in an interactive Excel tool.

Before you start the Evaluability Assessment, it will be helpful to have a rough draft of the Logic Model. This will assist you in answering the various questions in the Evaluability Assessment. See the guidance and template for creating a Logic Model.

Access the Evaluability Assessment tool here.

There is general guidance explaining how the Evaluability Assessment works.

There is step-by-step guidance to lead you through the Evaluability Assessment checklists.

components.html: When you have completed the Evaluability Assessment and a Level of Evaluation has been agreed by the Executive Director or their representative:
components.label: Content
At what Level will the evaluation be conducted?
HTML
components.content:
You will need to complete an Evaluation Assessment to determine the appropriate Level of Evaluation. It involves answering a series questions about the program, core service or policy initiative, in an interactive Excel tool.

Before you start the Evaluability Assessment, it will be helpful to have a rough draft of the Logic Model. This will assist you in answering the various questions in the Evaluability Assessment. See the guidance and template for creating a Logic Model.

There is step-by-step guidance to lead you through the Evaluability Assessment checklists.

components.html: When you have completed the Evaluability Assessment and a Level of Evaluation has been agreed by the Executive Director or their representative:
components.label: Content
At what Level will the evaluation be conducted?
Is it an S-CAP funded program?
HTML
components.content:
Read the guidance for S-CAP funded programs. This explains how to:
  • Link S-CAP reporting to evaluation
  • Synchronize the timing of reviews
  • Incorporate application-based funding into a logic model
It will help to minimize duplication and thereby streamline your work.

components.html:
Program design elements

Based on the agreed Level of Evaluation, certain design elements are required or are optional. These are listed in the the flowchart below. The flowchart also shows the order in which they will need to be completed, and provides some detail of the requirements for each.
components.label: Content
HTML
components.content:
Here is a list of the program design elements to be completed at the agreed Level of Evaluation, with links to the relevant templates and guidance, which includes worked examples:

Logic Model
  • Template
  • Guidance
  • Summary guidance and worked examples
Table of Indicators
  • Template
  • Guidance
  • Creating Good Indicators guidance

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Evaluation Plan

The Evaluation Plan is completed after all the other program design elements are finalized. It contains links to all the documentation for completed design elements.
  • Template
  • Guidance

components.label: Completed design elements
components.description: Check each box when the design element has been completed.

components.html: Click on the tab above: Implementation Phase. This shows evaluation tasks to be carried out once the design process is complete and the program is underway.
components.label: Content

components.html: After reviewing the 'Implementation Phase' tab, and when all of the design elements have been completed and ticked-off, you have completed this Workflow Checklist. Good luck with the implementation and evaluation!
components.label: Content
HTML
components.content:
Interim Reviews

These will usually be completed annually. They assess progress that has been made and issues that may be affecting implementation. There is a template to be completed, with accompanying guidance:
  • Interim Review template
  • Interim Review guidance

components.label: HTML
components.content: You should consult the S-CAP guidance when you do your Interim Review.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Final Evaluation Report

This is completed as the program comes to a close. It assesses the extent to which planned outcomes have been achieved, and considers lessons to be learned. There is a template to be completed, with accompanying guidance:
  • Final Evaluation Report template
  • Final Evaluation Report guidance

components.label: Is it an S-CAP funded program?
HTML
components.content:
Read the guidance for S-CAP funded programs. This explains how to:
  • Link S-CAP reporting to evaluation
  • Synchronize the timing of reviews
  • Incorporate application-based funding into a logic model
It will help to minimize duplication and thereby streamline your work.

components.label: Will there be involvement of third-party implementers?
HTML
components.content: Read the guidance on third-party implementers. This explains how to include evaluation in the request for proposals (RFP). This is important to ensure that the implementer incorporates evaluation tasks such as collecting data into their workplan.

components.html: A Level 5 evaluation is a full-scale evaluation and will probably involve contracting-in evaluation expertise. It tends to be applied only to large scale, complex programs that are high priority and/or high profile, and which involve a range of risks. The evaluation will be constructed to assess causality and test if achievement of outcomes can be attributed to the program.

components.label: Content

components.html:
Since core services do not generally have a defined starting point, a date will need to be set for the start of the evaluation. This could be: 

  • When there is a scheduled annual review or equivalent
  • When a cycle of funding is ending, or a new cycle is being launched
  • When a contract is coming up for review or renewal.
components.label: Content
HTML
components.content:
Interim Reviews

Interim Reviews will usually be completed after 2 years from the agreed start date for the evaluation. They assess what has been achieved so far and issues that may be affecting progress. There is a template to be completed, with accompanying guidance:
  • Interim Review template
  • Interim Review guidance

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Final Evaluation Report

Since core services are generally ongoing, a reasonable date in the future will need to be determined to conduct the final evaluation. This may be 4 years from when the evaluation starts.

The Final Evaluation Report is completed as the evaluation period comes to a close. It assesses the extent to which planned outcomes have been achieved. There is a template to be completed, with accompanying guidance:
  • Final Evaluation Report template
  • Final Evaluation Report guidance

components.label: Content
HTML
components.content:
Final Evaluation Report

Policy initiatives will usually not have a defined end-point, beyond the policy coming into force. A reasonable date in the future needs to be set for the end of the evaluation period. This is when the Final Evaluation Report will be completed. It should match the expected completion date that you have provided in the Evaluation Plan, and might be up to 3 years after the policy has come into force.

The Final Evaluation Report assesses the extent to which planned outcomes of the policy initiative have been achieved. There is a template to be completed, with accompanying guidance:
  • Final Evaluation Report template
  • Final Evaluation Report guidance
